titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Annette Sara Cunningham Papers on the Irish Export Board AIA.071
titlestmt.author: Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-11-30 13:02:37 -0500.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: Annette Sara Cunningham Papers on the Irish Export Board

physdesc.extent: in 1 manuscript box and 2 folders in shared oversize flat boxes

did.abstract: Anne Sara Cunnginham worked as the Press and Information Officer in North America for the Irish Export Board during the 1970s and 1980s. The Irish Export Board (Córas Tráchtala) was an economic development agency that emphasized marketing Irish-owned businesses and Irish products to global audiences. This collection contains photographs, catalogs, brochures, advertisements, printed ephemera, press releases, and newspaper articles documenting the Board's activities in North America, with specific fashion or home furnishing campaigns revealing the strategies and attempts to create an identity for Irish business that extended beyond agrarian stereotypes.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Anne Sara Cunnginham worked as the Press and Information Officer in North America for the Irish Export Board during the 1970s and 1980s. The Irish Export Board (Córas Tráchtala) was an economic development agency that emphasized marketing Irish-owned businesses and Irish products to global audiences. The Board was founded in 1959 and later merged with a private company. Enterprise Ireland, a government organization devoted to the growth and development of Irish businesses in global markets, superseded the Irish Export Board and other similar organizations. The Irish Export Board often emphasized fashion, home furnishings, and other consumer products, with notable campaigns focusing on Irish whiskey, a series of events at Bloomingdale's flagship New York City store, and the Statue of Liberty Centennial in 1986. During this time period, the Board and other similar organizations worked to create an identity for Irish businesses that extended beyond agrarian stereotypes, offering an alternate image of Ireland as a source for luxurious and well-designed products.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by Annette Sara Cunningham are held by Annette Sara Cunningham. Permission to publish or reproduce materials to which she holds copyright must be secured from the copyright holder. Please contact the Tamiment Library for assistance with contacting Annette Sara Cunningham.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Annette Cunningham in May 2013. The accession number associated with this gift is 2014.114.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Annette Cunningham Papers on the Irish Export Board; AIA 071; box number; folder number; Archives of Irish America, Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Materials were received loose and unarranged in a plastic bag. Materials were rehoused in acid-free folders and boxes, described by an archivist, and arranged in alphabetical order due to the absence of any original order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection contains photographs, catalogs, brochures, advertisements, printed ephemera, press releases, and newspaper articles concerning the Irish Export Board (Córas Tráchtala) in New York City. The materials document the Board's activities in North America, with specific fashion or home furnishing campaigns revealing the strategies and attempts to create an identity for Irish business that extended beyond agrarian stereotypes. Notable campaigns present in the collection include a series of events at Bloomingdale's flagship New York City store and the Statue of Liberty Centennial in 1986.

unittitle.emph: Treasures of Early Irish Art, 1500 BC to 1500 AD
